headline: In Fremont visit, Tim Ryan talks jobs, manufacturing and challenging China
author: Daniel Carson
sentences: With that in mind, Ryan visited Sandusky County and talked about the need for rebuilding the country with a vibrant middle class, strengthening Ohio's advanced manufacturing base, and challenging China on the world stage.
With roots in the Youngstown area, Ryan said he has a certain amount of rapport with working class voters, can understand their issues and knows what they're going through in their day-to-day lives.
If Ryan advances out of the Democratic primary, he would face the winner of a crowded Republican Senate primary that includes former state treasurer Josh Mandel, venture capitalist and author J.D.
As Americans emerge from a two-year COVID-19 pandemic, Ryan said this is a moment where this generation, like previous generations, has to prove that the United States is an exceptional country.

Elected to U.S. House in 2002
Ryan, a Democrat first elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 2002, is serving his 10th term in Congress and represents Ohio’s 13th Congressional District.
FREMONT —Tim Ryan feels his Ohio U.S. Senate campaign has an obligation to go beyond the Democrat/Republican narrative and engage voters of all political backgrounds in every part of the state.
To stay competitive, there needs to be a continued push for high-speed broadband infrastructure everywhere and a focus on advanced technologies, like the production of electric cars, Ryan said.
Ryan told Sandusky County supporters he had made inroads with some longtime Republican voters who had backed President Donald Trump in the last two presidential elections.
Brown stands out as one of the few Democrats in recent memory to win a statewide election in Ohio, defeating Republican Jim Renacci in his 2018 Senate reelection campaign.

There are a significant number of Trump voters who don't want to spend the next 10 years in what Ryan described as "culture wars," the candidate said.
I don't want anyone in the state to feel like we're not going to represent them," Ryan told supporters Saturday at Kohler's 818 Club in Fremont.
Ryan said Brown has always been visible throughout the state in rural counties and made a connection with working people across Ohio.
He said driving the conversation toward jobs, manufacturing and competing with China has resonated with those voters.
The Democrat said Ohio's voters don't have to agree with him on every issue in the Senate race.
Ryan said candidates need to have the mindset that voters aren't Democrats or Republicans.
Fremont marked one of three Ryan campaign stops Saturday, along with Parma and Defiance.
Ryan said one way to compete with China globally is with a cohesive industrial policy.
Senator Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, has endorsed Ryan in the 2022 U.S. Senate race.
"We're kind of working off his blueprint," Ryan said of Brown.
